quiz.title: Table Relations in SQL Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.

If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.question_text: I want to establish a relationship between a genres table and a books table. What kind of key would I need to add to the books table to establish this relationship?

answers.comments: Exactly! The foreign key refers to the primary key in another table.
Not quite. The primary key refers to the row in the current table. Which key refers to a different table?
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. The primary key refers to the row in the current table. Which key
refers to a different table?

answers.comments: Not quite. It's likely that the key will be an integer, but that's not the correct name.
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. It's likely that the key will be an integer, but that's not the
correct name.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: We have two tables: users and posts. A user has many posts, and a post belongs to a user. How should we relate the two tables to one another?

answers.text: Put a user_id foreign key on the posts table pointing to the id primary key in the users table.
answers.html: Put a user_id foreign key on the posts table pointing to the id primary key in the users table.
answers.comments: Yes! We can store which user a post belongs to by having each post point to a user.
answers.comments_html:
Yes! We can store which user a post belongs to by having each post point to a
user.

answers.text: Put a post_id foreign key on the users table pointing to the id primary key in the posts table.
answers.html: Put a post_id foreign key on the users table pointing to the id primary key in the posts table.
answers.comments: Not quite. This would allow a user to have only one post.

answers.text: Create a join table that points to both users and posts
answers.html: Create a join table that points to both users and posts
answers.comments: We can actually relate the users and posts without a join table. How can we do that?
answers.comments_html:
We can actually relate the users and posts without a join table. How can we do
that?

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: We have two tables: users and posts. A user has many posts, and a post belongs to a user. To create this relationship, you would add the foreign key to the users table.

answers.comments: Remember, in a one-to-many association, the foreign key should be on the table of the record that belongs to a record in the other table, in this case posts.
answers.comments_html: Remember, in a one-to-many association, the foreign key should be on the table of the record that belongs to a record in the other table, in this case posts.

answers.comments: Correct! In a one-to-many association, the foreign key should be on the table of the record that belongs to a record in the other table, in this case posts.
answers.comments_html: Correct! In a one-to-many association, the foreign key should be on the table of the record that belongs to a record in the other table, in this case posts.

questions.question_text: Which types of joins are supported by SQLite?

answers.comments: Correct! This will return all rows when there's at least one match in both tables.
answers.comments_html:
Correct! This will return all rows when there's at least one match in both
tables.

answers.comments: Exactly! This returns all rows from the left table and the matching rows from the right table.
answers.comments_html:
Exactly! This returns all rows from the left table and the matching rows from
the right table.

answers.comments: This is a valid SQL join type, but it's not supported by SQLite, and it's much less common than INNER and LEFT joins.
answers.comments_html: This is a valid SQL join type, but it's not supported by SQLite, and it's much less common than INNER and LEFT joins.

answers.comments: This is a valid SQL join type, but it's not supported by SQLite, and it's much less common than INNER and LEFT joins.
answers.comments_html: This is a valid SQL join type, but it's not supported by SQLite, and it's much less common than INNER and LEFT joins.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Our database has two tables: cocktails and restaurants. The same cocktail can be served by many restaurants, and each restaurant serves many different cocktails. How can we relate cocktails to restaurants?

answers.text: Create a join table where each row relates a cocktail with a restaurant
answers.comments: Perfect! This is a many-to-many relationship, so we need a join table that has cocktail_id and restaurant_id columns.
answers.comments_html:
Perfect! This is a many-to-many relationship, so we need a join table that has
cocktail_id and restaurant_id columns.

answers.text: Add a cocktail_id column (foreign key) to the restaurants table
answers.html: Add a cocktail_id column (foreign key) to the restaurants table
answers.comments: Not quite. This would allow restaurants to serve only a single cocktail. A restaurant would belong to a cocktail.
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. This would allow restaurants to serve only a single cocktail. A
restaurant would belong to a cocktail.

answers.text: Add a restaurant_id column (foreign key) to the cocktails table
answers.html: Add a restaurant_id column (foreign key) to the cocktails table
answers.comments: Not quite. This would mean each cocktail could be served at only one restaurant. A cocktail would belong to a restaurant.
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. This would mean each cocktail could be served at only one restaurant.
A cocktail would belong to a restaurant.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: We have two tables: dogs and owners. All of the owners have dogs, but not all dogs belong to an owner â€” some are strays. Which query will return ALL of the dogs and their matching owners?

answers.text: SELECT * FROM dogs LEFT JOIN owners ON dogs.owner_id = owners.id;
answers.html:
SELECT * FROM dogs
LEFT JOIN owners ON dogs.owner_id = owners.id;
answers.comments: Correct! dogs is the left table, so all of the dogs will be returned, even if they don't have an owner. Matching owners will also be returned.
answers.comments_html: Correct! dogs is the left table, so all of the dogs will be returned, even if they don't have an owner. Matching owners will also be returned.

answers.text: SELECT * FROM owners LEFT JOIN dogs ON dogs.owner_id = owners.id;
answers.html:
SELECT * FROM owners
LEFT JOIN dogs ON dogs.owner_id = owners.id;
answers.comments: Not quite. This will actually return all of the owners and their matching dogs. Which query will give us every dog?
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. This will actually return all of the owners and their matching
dogs. Which query will give us every dog?

answers.text: SELECT * FROM dogs INNER JOIN owners ON dogs.owner_id = owners.id;
answers.html:
SELECT * FROM dogs
INNER JOIN owners ON dogs.owner_id = owners.id;
answers.comments: Not quite. This will actually only return dogs that have an owner. Which query will give us every dog?
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. This will actually only return dogs that have an owner. Which query
will give us every dog?

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: A join table creates a many-to-many relationship between two other tables.

answers.comments: Correct! To set up a many-to-many relationship, we use a join table that has common fields from two or more other tables.
answers.comments_html:
Correct! To set up a many-to-many relationship, we use a join table that has
common fields from two or more other tables.

answers.comments: A join table is used to set up a many-to-many relationship. You may want to review the source/s for this question.
answers.comments_html: A join table is used to set up a many-to-many relationship. You may want to review the source/s for this question.
